ygData.subject: Multiple networks
ygData.msgSnippet: I ve been thinking about using conflicting networks/controllers operating the same set of inputs and outputs. My thoughts revolve around a weighted summing

------=_NextPart_000_1FF4_01C40B64.2720E980
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

I've been thinking about using 'conflicting' networks/controllers
operating the same set of inputs and outputs. 
My thoughts revolve around a weighted summing device that recieves both
the ouput and an associated confidence from each network, and the output
of the system is a function of the confidence levels ( sudden rise in
confidence having more meaning than a steady state confidence ) and the
outputs of the functions.
This approach might allow for a coupling of seemingly incompatable
networks or controllers, such as a LSTM to recognize features in a
landscape, an evolved neural network for obsticle avoidence, and a
conventional controller for 'after-market' behaviour add-ons, with out
re-evolving or re-teaching the previous networks.
The idea sounds like fun, except that I have no idea how to go about
teaching anything how to describe how confident it is in its own output.
Any thoughts? 


------=_NextPart_000_1FF4_01C40B64.2720E980

<HTML>
<BODY>
I've been thinking about using 'conflicting' networks/controllers operating the same set of inputs and outputs. <br>
My thoughts revolve around a weighted summing device that recieves both the ouput and an associated confidence from each network, and the output of the system is a function of the confidence levels ( sudden rise in confidence having more meaning than a steady state confidence ) and the outputs of the functions.<br>
This approach might allow for a coupling of seemingly incompatable networks or controllers, such as a LSTM to recognize features in a landscape, an evolved neural network for obsticle avoidence, and a conventional controller for 'after-market' behaviour add-ons, with out re-evolving or re-teaching the previous networks.<br>
The idea sounds like fun, except that I have no idea how to go about teaching anything how to describe how confident it is in its own output.<br>
Any thoughts?
</BODY></HTML>
<BR>
